summary: porcine epidemic diarrhea (PED) is a swine infectious disease characterized by levels of susceptibility, high incidence, and fatality. the virus is the causative agent of PED, which was discovered in 1978 (6). PEDV invades the digestive system of pigs through the nose and mouth. porcine small intestinal epithelial cells were used as an in vitro model to investigate PEDV infection. real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction was used to detect differences in expression of the RIG-1, PKR, OAS1, Mx1 and Mx2 genes at various time points post-infection. primer premier 5.0 software was used to design real-time PCR primers across gene exons. the gene was used as an internal control. the primers were synthesized by Sangon Biological Engineering Co., Ltd. 105 cells per well were discarded, the cells were washed twice in PBS. 300 L of the PEDV solution (MOI = 0.1) was added into each well. three replicates were placed in each group and cultured for 2 h. pathological changes of the cells during each infection period were observed. 2O with a thermocycling program of 40 cycles of 95°C for 30 s, 95°C for 5 s, and 60°C for 34 s. a melting curve analysis was executed after amplification as follows: 95°C for 15 s, 60°C for 1 min; 95°C for 15 s.
